title: Redgauntlet: A Tale Of The Eighteenth Century
author: Scott, Walter
snippet: 'In troth, dame,' answered Willie, 'ye are no sae far wrang; sae if mycomrade is to take his dance, ye maun gie me my drink, and then bob itaway like Madge of Middlebie.'

title: Memoirs of the Life of Sir Walter Scott, Volume 6
author: Lockhart, J. G. (John Gibson)
snippet: I am a suitor to the Duke, with little     expectation of success (for I know his engagements), for the kirk     of Middlebie to George Thomson, the very Abraham Adams of     Presbytery.

title: Memoirs of the Life of Sir Walter Scott, Volume 6
author: Lockhart, J. G. (John Gibson)
snippet: Should your Grace     find yourself at liberty to give countenance to this very     innocent and deserving creature, I need not say it will add to     the many favors you have conferred on me; but I hope the     parishioners will have also occasion to say, "Weel bobbit, George     of Middlebie."

title: Memoirs of the Life of Sir Walter Scott, Volume 6
author: Lockhart, J. G. (John Gibson)
snippet: I     conclude your Grace has already heard from fifty applicants that     the kirk of Middlebie is vacant, and I come forward as the     fifty-first (always barring prior engagements and better claims)     in behalf of George Thomson, a son of the minister of Melrose,     being the grinder of my boys, and therefore deeply entitled to my     gratitude and my good offices, as far as they can go.

title: Memoirs of the life of Sir Walter Scott,
author: Lockhart, J. G.
snippet: " It is doomed this letter is not to close without a request, i conclude your Grace has already heard from fifty applicants that the kirk of Middlebie is vacant, and I come forward as the fifty-first (always barring prior engagements and better claims) in behalf of George Thomson, a son of the minister of Melrose, being the grinder of my boys, and therefore deeply entitled to my gratitude and my good offices as far as they jan go.

title: Reminiscences
author: Carlyle, Thomas
snippet: The assemblage was large and earnest, gathered in the Middlebie road, a little way off the main street and highway.

title: Reminiscences
author: Carlyle, Thomas
snippet: The specific Roman town of Middlebie  is about half a mile below the Kirk (i. e. eastward of it) and is called by the country people " tbe Birrens " (i. e. the Scrags or Haggles,  I should think), a place lying all in dimples and wrinkles, with ruined houses if you dig at all, grassy but inarable part of whicb is still kept sacred in lea by "the Duke" (of Queensberry, now of Buccleuch and Queensberry), while the rest has been all dug to powder in the last sixty or seventy years by the adjoining little lairds.

title: Reminiscences
author: Carlyle, Thomas
snippet: Three Roman stations, with Carlisle (Caer Lewel, as old as King Solomon) for mother : Netherbie, Middlebie, and Ower- bie (or Upperby) in Eskdale.

title: Reminiscences
author: Carlyle, Thomas
snippet: I must not dwell on these things, yet will mention the other brother, my grand -uncle Francis, still remembered by his title, " the Captain of Middlebie."

title: Reminiscences
author: Carlyle, Thomas
snippet: He worked as carpenter, I know not how long, about Middlebie  ; then laid aside that craft (except as a side business, for he always had tools which I myself have assisted him in grinding) aud went to Brownknowe to farm.

title: Reminiscences
author: Carlyle, Thomas
snippet: His mother, whose name I have forgotten, was early left a widow with two of them, in the parish, perhaps in the village, of Middlebie.

title: Waverley Novels. (Abbotsford edition.)

snippet: " In troth, dame," answered Willie, "ye are nosae far wrang ; sae if my comrade is to take hisdance, ye maun gie me my drink, and then bob itaway like Madge of Middlebie."
